properties.description: Up to 90% of people living with dementia will experience distressed behaviour as a result of unmet needs, but the majority of it is preventable. We’ve built the first AI tool that predicts distressed behaviour in dementia care, before it happens, giving carers real-time & evidence-based support to prevent distress, prevent crises, reduce medication, and meet people's needs effectively.
properties.how_does_your_company_use_innovation__th:
We’re combining behavioural science with machine learning to do something that hasn’t been done before in dementia care: predict distressed behaviour before it happens.

Instead of waiting for things to go wrong and reacting in crisis, Less Distress is an app that uses real-world care data to spot early warning signs and guide carers in real time. It’s personalised, preventative, and based on the science of why behaviour happens in the first place, something most systems completely ignore.

Our innovation isn’t just in the tech, it’s in the model. We’re giving frontline carers access to the kind of behavioural insight that’s usually locked away in specialist services, and doing it in a way that’s fast, affordable, easy to use on the job, and a globally scalable solution.
properties.how_does_your_product_contribute_to_a_he:
Less Distress is about making things better for everyone involved in dementia care: The person, the carer, and the family.

All behaviour happens for a reason. In dementia, that reason is often an unmet need, but it’s very hard for carers to understand what the need is without proper training (which they very rarely receive). We help carers see what the behaviour is trying to say, so they can respond in a way that meets the need, not just manages the reaction.

When carers can predict distress before it happens, they can step in early and calmly, rather than reacting in crisis. Right now, when distressed behaviour is difficult for carers to support with, people are given unlicensed antipsychotics just to keep them sedated even though the side effects can be devastating: sedation, stroke, and death. It’s not person-centred care, it’s damage control.

Less Distress helps change that. We give carers real tools, grounded in behavioural science, so they can reduce medication, prevent placement breakdowns, and support the person effectively. That means more dignity, more calm, and more moments where people feel understood, not lost.

When it feels like no one cares...emwillcare
properties.name: emwillcare
properties.please_expand:
I’m not just looking for money, I’m looking for real partnership that brings not just funding, but support, mentorship, and guidance from people who’ve done this before and can help me take what I’ve started and turn it into something huge.

The AI company we’re working with built our prototype for free, and they’re still developing with us at no cost, because they believe in what we’re doing. It's the same with our marketing support. People are giving their time and skills because they’ve seen the impact that I have as a behaviour analyst, and they believe in me to make it happen.

In July, I’ll be pitching to investors for the first time at an Alzheimer’s Society event. I know my field, I’m one of only 80 behavioural analysts in the world who specialise in dementia. What I need now is someone who can help me build this into a service that’s available to everyone who needs it at a devastating time in their life.

I’m here to deliver and I’m the right person for this job. I’ll be the best entrepreneur you’ve ever worked with. I care for the people I help and want to make their lives better on a wider scale than I can do in-person. I make change happen, I’ve done it all my life (I started my other business 4 years ago, the first behavioural consultancy business in the UK for dementia care). And now I’m ready to do it on a much bigger scale to help millions of people.
properties.what_best_describes_your_stage_of_busine: I have a business that I want to scale
properties.what_is_your_usp__what_makes_you_differe:
There are currently no competitors in the field. I’m one of only 80 behaviour analysts in the whole world specialising in dementia care, and I’ve spent years working directly with carers, trying to stop distress before it spirals into crisis. However, there is only so many people I can help in-person.

'Less Distress', by emwillcare takes my knowledge and expertise and is the first tool that actually predicts distressed behaviour using behavioural science and AI, not just tracking what’s already gone wrong, but helping carers know what to do next, in real time. This isn’t just innovation, it’s a lifeline for caregivers.

We are supported by the Alzheimer's Society Launchpad programme, and Business Wales Accelerator Growth Programme.
properties.where_is_your_business_based_: UK but wanting to scale to US

founder_profiles.name: Dr Emma Williams
founder_profiles.background_summary: Dr Emma Williams is a UK-based expert in dementia care with over 27 years of experience. She holds a PhD in Psychology from Bangor University and is the founder of EmWill Care, a company focused on revolutionising dementia care by integrating behavioural science with smart technology, notably through their 'Less Distress' tool. She previously founded PACT (Positive Ageing Consultancy & Training) and has held leadership roles such as Director of Training for the North Wales Regional Partnership Board. Dr Williams is actively involved in accelerator programs with the Alzheimer's Society and Business Wales, and is recognised for her thought leadership and commitment to improving dementia care.

previous_companies.description: Founded and led a consultancy focused on positive ageing and training in dementia care.
Led training initiatives and provided behavioural consultancy in dementia care.

public_speaking_or_content.title: Showcasing 'Less Distress' at London Tech Week

investment_criteria_assessment.assessment_summary: From research_prospect_tool output: Dr Emma Williams and EmWill Care are a strong fit for Flight Story's investment criteria, with deep sector expertise, a mission-driven and innovative solution, relevant founder experience, and evidence of thought leadership and strategic capability.

company_profile.description: emwillcare is a company dedicated to transforming dementia care by ensuring individuals living with dementia receive the best possible support while empowering their caregivers with effective, evidence-based strategies. They focus on reducing placement breakdowns, minimizing the use of unlicensed antipsychotic drugs, lowering health and social care costs, and improving quality of life for those affected by dementia. Their approach includes practical behavioral tools, personalized data-driven care, and innovative digital services like Less Distress, which predicts and prevents distressed behaviors.
key_products_services: Less Distress - a digital service predicting and preventing distressed behaviors in dementia care
company_profile.business_model: emwillcare operates by providing innovative behavioral science-based tools and digital services to care home owners and commissioners, aiming to improve dementia care quality, reduce crisis situations, and lower costs associated with staffing and medication.
company_profile.target_customer: Care home owners and commissioners seeking cost-effective solutions that enhance dementia care quality.
company_profile.mission_statement: To transform dementia care by ensuring that individuals living with dementia receive the best possible support, while empowering their caregivers with effective, evidence-based strategies.

market_analysis.industry_overview: Health technology (health-tech) encompasses the application of organized knowledge and skills in the form of devices, medicines, vaccines, procedures, and systems developed to solve health problems and improve quality of life. The industry includes digital health, telemedicine, electronic health records, wearable devices, health apps, and advanced medical devices. Health-tech aims to enhance healthcare delivery, improve patient outcomes, and increase efficiency through technological innovation.
market_analysis.target_market_segment: Healthcare providers (hospitals, clinics, physicians), patients/consumers, payers (insurance companies), pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies, and government/public health agencies. Key segments include telehealth users, remote patient monitoring, digital therapeutics, and AI-driven diagnostics.
key_market_trends: Rapid adoption of AI and machine learning for diagnostics, workflow automation, and personalized medicine
Expansion of telemedicine and remote patient monitoring
Growth in wearable health devices and Internet of Medical Things (IoMT)
Increased focus on patient-centered care and digital health consumerism
Integration of virtual and augmented reality for training and treatment
Rising use of cloud-based healthcare IT solutions
Emphasis on data interoperability and secure health information exchange
Emergence of generative AI as a virtual assistant for clinicians
market_analysis.competitor_landscape_summary: The global health-tech market is highly fragmented, with a mix of established medical device and IT companies, digital health startups, and tech giants. Leading players are differentiated by technological innovation, scale, and integration capabilities. M&A activity and strategic partnerships are common as companies seek to expand their digital health portfolios and global reach.

competitors.name: Siemens Healthineers AG
weaknesses: High dependence on capital equipment sales

competitors.name: Medtronic
weaknesses: Competition from emerging digital health startups

competitors.name: EPIC Systems Corporation
strengths: Dominant EHR platform in the US

company_competitive_advantages: Proprietary AI and data analytics capabilities
Strong partnerships with healthcare providers and payers
Robust cybersecurity and data privacy measures
barriers_to_entry: Complex and varying regulatory requirements across regions
High capital and R&D investment needs
Data privacy and security compliance (e.g., HIPAA, GDPR)
Interoperability and integration with legacy healthcare systems
Entrenched relationships with existing vendors (vendor lock-in)
Cultural resistance to technology adoption among providers
market_analysis.market_timing_assessment: Favorable; the market is in a strong growth phase driven by digital transformation, increased healthcare spending, and post-pandemic acceleration of telehealth and remote care. High innovation and funding activity, but also increasing competition.
market_analysis.regulatory_environment: The global health-tech regulatory landscape is complex and fragmented, with significant differences between regions. Key frameworks include the US FDA for medical devices and digital health, the EU MDR and GDPR for data protection, and country-specific requirements. Companies must navigate approval processes, data privacy laws, and interoperability standards. Regulatory harmonization is limited, requiring tailored compliance strategies for each market.
